You may find it useful on the job, though. TABLE 23-1 Common Scripting File Types ### Scripting Tools You can create a script in any app that creates plaintext files, including Notepad. Fancier scripting programs can be acquired, or in some cases they are built into the operating system, such as the Microsoft PowerShell Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE) seen in [Figure 23-1](ch23.xhtml#ch23fig1). FIGURE 23-1 Microsoft PowerShell IS These tools enhance your script-writing experience by providing Color coding of special keyword types Built-in help system to ease the pain of learning syntax Auto-fill that makes suggestions as you type Ability to run the entire script without leaving the editor Ability to run selected lines in a script to test them ### Data Types The supported data types and related syntax vary between scripting languages, but most scripting languages support common data types such as strings and integers. #### Strings Scripts that deal with user names, filenames, and city names—anything that is a text string—will use some type of string data type. Some scripting language commands work only against certain data types, such as determining the number of characters in a string, as seen in the following JavaScript language where _username_ is the name of a variable and _length_ is a property, or characteristic, of that variable. Notice the dot separating the variable from the property. `username.length` #### Integers Integers are another common data type. An integer is a positive or negative whole number with no decimal places. The specific minimum and maximum values that can be used with integer values depend on your chosen scripting language. JavaScript uses a _number_ data type; there is no specific _integer_ data type. Microsoft PowerShell, on the other hand, does have a specific integer data type with a numeric range of –2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647. [Figure 23-2](ch23.xhtml#ch23fig2), using PowerShell, shows the creation of a variable called _age_ being set with a value of _50_. The _.GetType()_ method, or action, is being run against that variable and it returns _Int32,_ which indicates this is an integer variable. PowerShell variables are always preceded with a dollar sign. FIGURE 23-2 Microsoft PowerShell GetType() ### Variables To facilitate working with scripts, script writers often use custom names for values that change throughout their code; these are _variables_. Operating systems also have built-in variables called _environment variables_ that contain values such as the currently logged-on user name, home directory path, version of the operating system, and so on. #### Environment Variables You can use environment variables in your scripts as needed. The syntax to accomplish this varies among scripting languages. [Figure 23-3](ch23.xhtml#ch23fig3) shows how the Linux _env_ command returns environment variables. FIGURE 23-3 Linux environment variables The same type of result is accomplished in a Windows command prompt (also in a batch file) using the _set_ command, as seen in [Figure 23-4](ch23.xhtml#ch23fig4). FIGURE 23-4 Using Windows environment variables through a command prompt We can view environment variables through PowerShell with the _Get-ChildItem env:_ command, as seen in [Figure 23-5](ch23.xhtml#ch23fig5). FIGURE 23-5 Using Windows environment variables through PowerShell #### Script Variables Imagine that you are writing a script that will list the running services on a Windows computer. If you need to use that list of running services over and over again in your code, it’s much more efficient to get the list of services only once, store it in a variable, and then reuse the variable rather than repeatedly getting the list of services each time it’s needed. The following Microsoft PowerShell example stores only running services in a variable named **$running_svcs** ; note that the built-in placeholder variable **$_** is being used to process all returned services—also notice the “equals” operator (**-eq**). `$running_svcs = Get-Service | Where{$_.status –eq "Running"}` Whenever you need to list running services in your script, you can simply refer to the **$running_svcs** variable name instead of issuing the original long command again. In PowerShell, you could ask a user to enter a cost center code, which would be stored in a variable: `$cost_center_code = Read-Host("Please enter a cost center:")` In Python, the same thing would look like this: `cost_center_code = raw_input("Please enter a cost center:")` ### Common Scripting Elements Regardless of the scripting language, scripters use certain common elements. Some are related to best practices, such as using comments to document your script. Other items are more functional, such as the conditional execution of commands. #### Comments Comments in scripts make reading the script much easier, even for the script creator after enough time has passed! They explain exactly what the script does and why it does it. Having that information readily available speeds up troubleshooting and script modifications. The way to indicate a comment in a script varies among scripting languages. [Table 23-2](ch23.xhtml#ch23tab2) provides examples of using comments in different scripting languages. TABLE 23-2 Using Comments in Scripts #### Conditional Execution Most languages have a method of running a command only if it meets a specific condition. The general format of an _if_ statement looks like this: The specific syntax varies between languages; if you’re using Python, it would look something like this: In PowerShell, the same example would look like the following sample code. Notice the age variable is being declared as an integer with **[int]** , and also notice the **–lt** operator, which stands for “less than”: #### Looping Loops execute a series of commands zero or more times depending on how they are coded. Sometimes you’ll know how many times you need to run the same code, such as checking ten input fields on a web page; you could run the JavaScript command for testing input validity ten times to ensure that all user input is acceptable. Other times you won’t know how many times you need to run the same code, such as when processing whatever number of files might exist in a subdirectory. Luckily, most scripting languages provide a multitude of looping options. ##### Loop Syntax Most scripting languages support different types of looping constructs. One common loop type is a _while_ loop that tests a condition. While the condition is true, the code within the loop executes. The following Microsoft PowerShell example displays a menu of options to the user until the user presses 3 (“Exit this menu”). In some scripting languages “not equal to” is expressed as `!=` or `<>`, but PowerShell uses **–ne** (not equal). The **switch** statement tests the value of what the user entered (stored in the **$user_entered_choice** variable). ### Active Directory User Logon Scripts Microsoft Active Directory uses a central network database containing user account definitions, groups, and computers, among other items. Commands can be executed via a script when users log on to a machine (also when they log off), whether that script is a batch file, a VB script, or PowerShell. Common uses of logon scripts include the following: Map network drives Set or read environment variables Deploy new software or software updates Run executable programs Any type of script will require the invoker to have permissions to run the script itself. Depending on what the script does, additional permissions might be required. For example, a Linux Shell script requires the invoker to have at least Read (r) and Execute (x) permissions. In [Figure 23-6](ch23.xhtml#ch23fig6), the **ls –l** command lists files with details, the **chmod** command adds the Execute permission for all users, and then the **ls –l** command shows the new permissions. FIGURE 23-6 Viewing and setting Linux Shell script permissions with the ls command Microsoft Group Policy in Active Directory enables the centralized configuration of user and computer settings. A user logon script can be specified in Group Policy, as shown in [Figure 23-7](ch23.xhtml#ch23fig7). The users affected by the group policy object (GPO) will run the logon script. FIGURE 23-7 Specifying a PowerShell logon script in Group Policy The following example shows how a batch file (.bat file) could map a drive for a user upon logon using the _username_ environment variable: `Net Use H: \\Server1\UserHome\%username%` We could map a drive letter to any shared folder through a PowerShell logon script (.ps1 file) like this: --- ## Appendix ## About the Online Content This book comes complete with: TotalTester Online customizable practice exam software with more than 400 practice exam questions Simulated performance-based questions Video training from the author Bonus glossary Exam Objective Map ### System Requirements The current and previous major versions of the following desktop browsers are recommended and supported: Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Firefox, and Safari. Exams can be taken in Practice Mode or Exam Mode. Practice Mode provides an assistance window with hints, references to the book, explanations of the correct and incorrect answers, and the option to check your answer as you take the test. Exam Mode provides a simulation of the actual exam. The number of questions, the types of questions, and the time allowed are intended to be an accurate representation of the exam environment. The option to customize your quiz allows you to create custom exams from selected domains or chapters, and you can further customize the number of questions and time allowed. To take a test, follow the instructions provided in the previous section to register and activate your Total Seminars Training Hub account. When you register, you will be taken to the Total Seminars Training Hub. From the Training Hub Home page, select your certification from the Study drop-down menu at the top of the page to drill down to the TotalTester for your book. You can also scroll to it from the list of Your Topics on the Home page, and then click on the TotalTester link to launch the TotalTester. Once you’ve launched your TotalTester, you can select the option to customize your quiz and begin testing yourself in Practice Mode or Exam Mode. All exams provide an overall grade and a grade broken down by domain. ### Other Book Resources The following sections detail the other resources available with your book. You can access these items by selecting the Resources tab, or by selecting CompTIA A+ Study Guide, 11e (Exams 220-1101 & 220-1102) from the Study drop-down menu at the top of the page or from the list of Your Topics on the Home page. The menu on the right side of the screen outlines all of the available resources. #### Performance-Based Questions In addition to multiple-choice questions, the CompTIA A+ exams include performance-based questions (PBQs), which, according to CompTIA, are designed to test your ability to solve problems in a simulated environment. More information about PBQs is provided on CompTIA’s website. You can access the performance-based questions included with this book by navigating to the **Resources** tab and selecting **Performance-Based Questions Quiz**. After you have selected the PBQs, an interactive quiz will launch in your browser. #### Video Training from the Author Video MP4 clips from the author of this book provide detailed examples of key certification objectives in audio/video format. You can access these videos by navigating to the **Resources** tab and selecting **Videos**. The videos are organized by chapter and by exercise and will launch in your Web browser. #### Glossary A bonus glossary for the book has been included for your review. You can access the glossary by navigating to the **Resources** tab and selecting **Glossary**. You can either view the glossary online in your web browser or you can select the download option in the menu to download a PDF. #### Exam Objective Map An Exam Objective Map for the book has been included for your review. The Exam Objective Map shows which chapters cover individual CompTIA A+ exam objectives for both exams 220-1101 and 220-1102. You can access the map by navigating to the **Resources** tab and selecting **Exam Objective Map**. You can either view the Exam Objective Map online in your Web browser or you can select the Download option in the menu to download a PDF. ### Technical Support For questions regarding the TotalTester or operation of the Training Hub, visit **[www.totalsem.com](http://www.totalsem.com)** or e-mail **[support@totalsem.com](mailto:support@totalsem.com)**. (19) **RADIUS**  _See_ Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service (RADIUS). **RAID**  _See_ redundant array of independent disks. **RAID 0** A RAID array in which every time data writes to disk, a portion (block) is written to each disk in turn, creating a “stripe” of data across the member disks. RAID 0 uses the total disk space in the array for storage, without protecting the data from drive failure. (9) **RAID 1** Also called mirroring, this RAID array type provides fault tolerance because all the data is written identically to the two drives in the mirrored set. (9) **RAID 5** A RAID method using three or more disks in which data is written in small blocks to each disk in turn, creating a “stripe” of data across the member disks. In each stripe, the portion on one disk is not the actual data, but the result of an algorithm performed on the data contained in the other blocks in the stripe. This block is called the parity block, and because of the space required, the total capacity in the array available for data storage is equal to the total disk space minus one entire disk. (9) **RAID 10** A RAID array that requires a minimum of four identical disks paired into two mirrored sets. Data is written between the two mirrored sets as if they were simply two disks in a RAID 0 array. This gives you the fault tolerance of a mirror and the performance of RAID 0. (9) **RAID array** Two or more disks working together in one of the several RAID schemes. (9) **RAID controller** Specialized hardware used to create and manage a RAID array. (9) **rail** A power pathway that delivers a specific voltage to a specific connection. Often used to describe the power supply output at a particular voltage, such as “the 12-volt rail.” (10) **RAM**  _See_ random access memory (RAM). **random access memory (RAM)** Memory that is accessible in any (random) order. (10, 14) **TPM**  _See_ Trusted Platform Module (TPM). **tracert** A command-line utility installed with the TCP/IP protocol suite that traces the route taken by packets to a destination. (19) **traces** The meshwork of copper lines on a motherboard that carries signals. (8) **trackball** A pointing device that moves an on-screen pointer by rolling a ball within a stationary device using fingers. (3) **trackpad**  _See_ touchpad. **tractor feed** A printer paper-feeding method requiring continuous-form paper, sheets of paper attached to each other at perforated joints, with perforations on the sides that fit over sprockets that turn, pulling the paper through the printer. (13) **transfer belt** In some color laser printers, a belt that transfers colors from each cartridge to the final printed page. (13) **transfer corona wire** In the laser printing process, a wire that passes a small positive charge to paper as it travels through the printer. This positive charge attracts the negatively charged toner particles on the drum to the paper. (13) **transfer roller** In the transferring stage of the laser printing imaging process, the roller that moves the positively charged paper as it passes the drum and pulls the toner image from the drum. (13) **transferring** In the laser printing process, the step in which the toner on the drum is transferred to the paper. (13) **Transmission Control Protocol (TCP)** One of the two main protocols of the TCP/IP protocol suite; breaks the data into chunks, called datagrams. Each datagram also contains information, stored in a header, that the TCP protocol uses on the receiving end to reassemble the chunks of data into the original message. (16) **Transport Layer Security (TLS)** A data encryption technology used for securing data transmitted over the Internet. TLS succeeded Secure Sockets Layer (SSL). (18) **tree** One or more Active Directory domains that share a contiguous namespace. For example, you might have two domains in a single tree: offize.xyz.com and warehouse.xyz.com. (20) **triple-channel** In reference to RAM architecture, a scheme for greatly increasing the speed of DRAM by which the memory controller chip alternates between three memory modules using a separate channel for each. (9) **Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP)** A UDP protocol running on port 69 for unsecure file transfers. Differs from FTP in that there is no option for authentication. (16) **Trojan horse** A virus that gains access to a computer by masquerading as a harmless program that a user innocently installs on the computer. (22) **troubleshooting** The act of discovering the cause of a problem and correcting it. (12) **Trusted Platform Module (TPM)** A special microchip installed on a motherboard that stores passwords, keys, and digital certificates. Various services, such as BitLocker, can store such security data in this chip. (4, 8, 20) **trusted source** A source of software that you trust to provide malware-free applications that will work reliably on a device. (15) **TTL**  _See_ time to live (TTL). **twisted nematic (TN)** The most common technology for an LCD monitor. It provides very good response rate and maximum refresh rate but is not as good as in-plane switching (IPS) in viewing angles and color reproduction. (10) **twisted-pair cable** Cable that consists of pairs of wires twisted around each other. The twists help to boost each wire’s signals and make them less susceptible to electromagnetic interference (EMI). _Compare to_ straight-pair cable. (5, 16) **two-in-one laptop** A laptop with a screen that rotates to convert it from a laptop to a tablet. Also called a convertible laptop. (14) **TXT records** A type of DNS record used to send human-readable information about a server or network, usually for spam management. (16) **type** A Windows command-line utility that concatenates, displays, or prints files. (5) **Type I client hypervisor** A Type I (bare metal) hypervisor designed for client computers (desktops or laptops). (7) **Type I hypervisor** A hypervisor that can run directly on a computer without an underlying host operating system. (7) **Type II hypervisor** A hypervisor that requires a host operating system. It cannot run on a computer that has no OS installed. (7) **UAC**  _See_ User Account Control (UAC). **Ubuntu Linux** A user-friendly distro of Linux designed for end-user desktop and laptop computers. (4) **UDF**  _See_ Uniqueness Database File (UDF). **UDP**  _See_ Universal Datagram Protocol (UDP). **UEFI**  _See_ Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI). **UI**  _See_ user interface (UI). **ultra-portable** The smallest laptop type, weighing less than three pounds. _See also_ netbook _and_ mini-notebook. (14) **unattended installation** An automated software installation that does not require a person to be present to respond to prompts for information. (4) **unauthorized account access** Access to an account without permission to do so. (15) **unauthorized device access** Access to a device without permission to do so. (15) **UNC**  _See_ Universal Naming Convention (UNC). **Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI)** A firmware specification that allows the OS to interact more closely with modern computer components and is a replacement for the traditional BIOS. (5, 8) **unified threat management (UTM)** The principle of creating a unified package of appliances that work together to reduce the threat of harm from attacks. A UTM solution might include IDS, IPS, VPN, firewalls, antimalware applications, and other tools. (18) **Uniform Resource Locator (URL)** A web page address. (18) **uninterruptible power supply (UPS)** A battery backup and power conditioner unit that regulates and supplements the power to connected devices as needed, including providing backup power from the battery when AC power from the wall outlet is inadequate or not present. _See also_ online UPS _and_ standby UPS. (1, 21) **Uniqueness Database File (UDF)** A file used with a scripted unattended installation along with an answer file. The UDF file provides settings that are unique for each computer. (4) **Universal Datagram Protocol (UDP)** A subprotocol of TCP/IP used for connectionless communications in which each packet is sent without establishing a connection. (16) **Universal Naming Convention (UNC)** A method for pointing to shares on a network that includes the name or IP address of the server and the name of the share on the server. It begins with two backslashes, and a single backslash separates the server name from the share name. (21) **Universal Plug and Play (UPnP)** A set of protocols for enabling network devices to discover each other’s network presence and establish working relationships. This term appears only in the Acronyms list in the A+ exam objectives. **Universal Serial Bus (USB)** An external bus that connects into the PC’s PCI bus. With USB, you can theoretically connect up to 127 devices to your computer on a single USB bus. (9) **unmanaged switch** A switch that has no configuration options and no interface with which to configure them. _Compare to_ managed switch. (16) **unshielded twisted-pair (UTP)** The most common type of twisted-pair wiring that has a plastic sheathing but does not have actual metal shielding. (3) **upgrade path** A compatibility between an old version and edition of an OS and a newer version and edition such that a computer can be upgraded without losing installed applications and files. (4) **UPS**  _See_ uninterruptible power supply (UPS). **URL**  _See_ Uniform Resource Locator (URL). **USB**  _See_ Universal Serial Bus (USB). **USB 2.0** A USB interface that transmits data at speeds up to 480 Mbps, which equals 60 megabytes per second (MBps) in half-duplex. (9) **USB 3.0** A USB standard that operates at up to 5 Gbps (625 MBps), which is ten times the speed of USB 2.0. It supports full-duplex communication. (9) **USB 3.1** An update to SuperSpeed USB (USB 3.0) that operates at up to 10 Gbps (1.25 GBps). It uses a USB Type C connector. (9) **USB 3.2** An update to USB 3.1 that operates at up to 20 Gbps (2.5 GBps). It uses a USB Type C connector. (9) **USB 4.0** An update to USB 3.1 that can support up to 40 Gbps throughput. It’s based on the Thunderbolt 3 specification and is required for Thunderbolt 4. **USB drive**  _See_ flash drive. (9) **USB hub** A multiport connecting device for USB devices. (9) **USB Type A connector** The standard USB connector for USB 1.1 through 3.0 connections on a computing device such as a personal computer. A USB cable that connects a computer to a peripheral usually has a Type A connector on one end and a Type B connector on the other. A Type A connector that can be used with USB 3.0 speed is physically compatible with USB 1.1 and 2.0 sockets but has more pins on the inside and is typically blue on the inside. (9) **USB Type B connector** The standard USB connector for USB 1.1 through 3.0 connections on a peripheral device such as a printer or scanner. A USB cable that connects a computer to a peripheral usually has a Type A connector on one end and a Type B connector on the other. A Type B connector that can be used with USB 3.0 speed is physically compatible with USB 1.1 and 2.0 sockets but has more pins on the inside and is typically blue on the inside. (9) **USB Type C connector** A connector used by USB 3.1 and Thunderbolt devices that provides both data and power to a device. (9) **USB-C**  _See_ USB Type C connector. **User Account Control (UAC)** A Windows security feature that prevents unauthorized system changes by prompting for permission. (20, 22) **user interface (UI)** The visual portion of an OS and the software components that allow the user to interact with the OS. (3) **user profile** Settings for each user who logs on that include registry settings saved in a registry file for that user. (6, 20) **User State Migration Tool (USMT)** A utility for migrating data from many computers, or if you need to perform what Microsoft calls a “wipe-and-load migration” from and to the same computer. (20) **vector** A method of malware infection, or how the infection reaches its target. (22) **version** A new level of an operating system or application with major changes to the core components. (3) **vertical alignment (VA) panel** A type of liquid crystal display (LCD) technology that is a compromise between twisted nematic (TN) and in-plane switching (IPS), offering advantages of both. VA panels support higher refresh rates, like TN panels, but support the higher color reproduction and better brightness and viewing angles of IPS. (10) **vertical position** An LCD display setting that adjusts the viewable area of the display vertically. (9) **Video Electronics Standards Organization**  _See_ VESA (Video Electronics Standards Organization). **video graphics array (VGA)** **1.** A video standard introduced with IBM PS/2 computers in the late 1980s. VGA has a maximum resolution of 720 × 400 in text mode and 640 × 480 in graphics mode. **2.** An HD-15 (DE-15) connector, which is a 15-pin D-sub connector with pins arranged in three rows used to connect monitors via an analog interface. (10) **video RAM (VRAM)** A specialized type of memory used only with video adapters. (7) **virtual machine monitor (VMM)** The software that creates a virtual machine, providing access to the necessary hardware on the host machine in isolation from the host operating system and other virtual machines. (7) **virtual memory** The use by the operating system of a portion of hard disk to swap data into and out of memory, increasing the available memory space. (4, 6) **virtual network** A virtual address space existing separate from a physical network. (7) **virtual network computing (VNC)** A protocol for remote access that is platform-independent (unlike RDP). Users at both ends can see the screen at the same time. (18) **VNC**  _See_ virtual network computing (VNC). **virtual private network (VPN)** A virtual tunnel created between two endpoints over an untrusted network. The tunnel is created by encapsulating the packets within special packets for the tunnel. Other security methods are also usually applied to a VPN, such as encrypting the data before encapsulating it, along with encrypted authentication. (17) **virtual technology**  _See_ hardware-assisted virtualization (HAV). **virtual world** A simulated environment within which participants create an online community. (7) **VirtualBox** A hypervisor produced by Oracle capable of running virtual machines on a PC desktop. (7) **virtualization** The creation of an environment that seems real but isn’t. (7) **Virtualization Technology (VT)** Intel’s term for their technologies that support virtualization. (8) **virtualization workstation** A computer used to support the on-screen simulation of a complete computer, including operating system and running applications. (7) **virus** A program installed and activated on a computer without the user’s knowledge or permission. At the very least, the intent is mischief, but most often, the intent is to cause damage. (22) **virus encyclopedia** A generic term for a collection of information on known malware (not just viruses). (22) **vishing** Phishing done via voice calls or voice mail. It issues keys per user and per session and includes encryption key integrity checking. It uses Temporal Key Integrity Protocol (TKIP). (17) **Wi-Fi Protected Access 2 (WPA2)** An improved version of WPA that does not support older network cards and offers both secure authentication and data encryption. It uses EAP for a variety of authentication methods—most often EAP-PSK. (17) **Wi-Fi Protected Access 3 (WPA3)** An improved version of WPA3 that has two encryption modes: personal (128-bit encryption) and enterprise (192-bit encryption). Instead of using EAP-PSK, it uses SAE, making the initial key exchange more secure. (17) **wildcard** At a command prompt, a character that substitutes for other characters. Windows PE supports the Windows Setup GUI, collecting configuration information. (4) **Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE)** A group of diagnostics and repair tools that runs within Windows PE.
